charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
We lost our lovely grandma and mother, June (aka Betty) on the 14 March 2021. June suffered from a severe heart condition, therefore her wish was for donations to this charity instead of flowers at her funeral.

Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charity’s aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

Thank you for your support and contributions.

story:
My dad, Brian Rowley, was a keen supporter of Guide Dogs. He was diagnosed with lung cancer in September 2020 and unfortunately caught Covid in hospital whilst being treated for another infection.  He sadly lost the difficult fight against this virus.  It was his wish that I did this run on behalf of Guide Dogs which is a very worthy cause and close to his heart.  I intend to give this everything I’ve got in honour of my dad - hope he will be watching so I can make him proud 💜💙💚

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Thank you for taking the time visit my JustGiving page. Below is some more information about why I have chosen to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital by running the London Marathon. 

At our 20 week scan whilst pregnant, we were told that our baby had a complication with his heart. Within the hour, we had been contacted by Great Ormond Street and had an appointment to see a specialist. 

Archer was diagnosed with a congenital heart defect (Transposition of the Great Arteries, Aortic Arch Hypoplasia and a Ventricular Septal Defect) and required lengthy open heart surgery in the first week of his life to correct this. Without this incredibly intricate surgery, he wouldn’t be with us today. At every stage of his journey, whether it be pre natal, in Cardiac Intensive Care or on the ward, Archer’s care was exceptional. The staff went above and beyond to ensure we were fully informed and helped us to understand his condition and treatment. All this in the midst of lockdown due to COVID-19, making the situation even more challenging.

Archer’s operation was successful and he was discharged after 3 weeks. He will require regular check ups to monitor how his heart is growing throughout his life, and Great Ormond Street will continue to support both him and our family.

We are eternally grateful for everything they have done and continue to do for our family.

Please support this incredible charity and help them to continue to help children like Archer, who wouldn’t be here today without them.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The RNLI has answered Mayday calls for nearly 200 years, from those called from sinking fishing boats, to families swimming on busy beaches, to dog walkers cut-off by the tide. It's the most urgent plea, used by mariners when life is in immediate danger and when their lifesavers hear those words they launch courageously into the unknown to help those who rely on their help.

This May, as summer approaches, they're the ones sending out a Mayday call. As we look forward to 2021 and beyond, they know that they'll be facing the busiest summer season for the lifesavers to come. And to keep them safe, ready and knowing they can handle whatever the summer brings, they need our help.

They're counting on us to answer their call and take on the Mayday Mile. Our support will help the crew stand strong as our busiest summer season approaches.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Amelia is turning 2 years old and she loves animals!
Her favourite now is a big plush elephant she calls Antant, because she knows her “Daddy loves her BIG - as big as an elephant!”.

But animals like elephants, pandas, gorillas, tigers and whales have had it tough the last few decades. And we should do everything we can to help.

We want our daughter to grow up in a world full of wildlife animals and we have made a direct donation in her name to the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) this year. 

Amelia sent out little ToyChoc boxes to her friends from a family owned UK manufacturer with very strong values supporting animals, the planet and our health. PLAYin CHOC teaches our kids about endangered animals through playing and treating themselves with a delicious organic chocolate. Check them out here: https://playinchoc.com/collections/endangered-animals 

Thank you for your donations or any other action to protect our wildlife! 

Amelia, Madara and Tommy

story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls to help make sure that health workers are protected in situations where they may be at risk, while £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves. 

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.
